sections.title: The Future of Philippine Internet (Post-2025)
sections.description: Amid the prevalence of COVID-19 in 2020, “67 percent of Filipinos had internet access” by January 2021. This pressed on the already-persisting issue of slow internet, however, with the nation ranking “84th out of 177” countries globally (Magahis & Santua, 2021).

image.alt: Individual wearing a mask and shield using a tablet during the COVID-19 pandemic

sections.title: The State of Philippine Internet
sections.description: The country's poor internet speeds prompted regulatory eases, permitting up to 100% foreign ownership as well as enacting The Subscriber Identity Module (SIM) Act in 2022 to aid in curbing illegal activity (“Philippines Country Commercial Guide”, 2024).

image.alt: Anonymous individual in a hoodie typing on a laptop

sections.title: Fiber-Optic Systems and Infrastructure
sections.description: “[P]layers are expected to…install fiber-optic…systems” to sustainably remedy the nation’s troubling speeds especially as the “number of…subscribers…will reach 159 million” by 2025. (“Philippines Country Commercial Guide”, 2024).

sections.title: The Puzzle Piece Awaiting Assembly
sections.description: As expressed by Dr. Torres, Philippine internet is a “puzzle still waiting to be assembled” with its vast milestones yet its equal hurdles unresolved; while we have the “pieces” we ultimately: “need to know how to put it all together” (Torres qtd. in Dimacali, 2011).
